modules.title: Organizational Forms, Corporate Issuer Features, and Ownership

concepts.title: Sole Proprietorship
concepts.desc: Single owner, unlimited liability, simple structure. Owner and business are legally identical. Limited life.

concepts.title: Partnership
concepts.desc: General partnership: all partners share unlimited liability. Limited partnership: GPs manage, LPs have limited liability.

concepts.title: Limited Company/Corporation
concepts.desc: Separate legal entity, limited liability for shareholders, perpetual life, easier capital raising, double taxation.

concepts.title: Public vs Private
concepts.desc: Public: listed on exchange, liquid shares, disclosure requirements. Private: fewer shareholders, less regulation, less liquid.

concepts.title: Going Public (IPO)
concepts.desc: Access to capital markets, increased liquidity. Costs: underwriting, disclosure, regulatory compliance.

concepts.title: Corporate Owners
concepts.desc: Institutional investors (pension funds, mutual funds, insurance), activist investors, sovereign wealth funds, PE firms, family/founders.

decisions.question: Public vs Private ownership?
use: Public: need broad capital access, growth capital, liquidity for shareholders
Private: want control, confidentiality, avoid regulatory burden
avoid: Going public too early without proper governance infrastructure

pitfalls: Corporations face double taxation: profits taxed at corporate level AND dividends taxed at personal level
Limited liability only protects shareholders' personal assets beyond their investment
Private companies may have higher cost of capital due to illiquidity

questions.question: Which organizational form provides limited liability to ALL owners?
questions.explanation: A corporation provides limited liability to all shareholders. In a limited partnership, only LPs have limited liability; GPs have unlimited liability.

questions.question: Double taxation of corporate income means:
options: The company pays taxes in two jurisdictions
Profits are taxed at the corporate level and dividends at the personal level
The tax rate is twice the standard rate
Both income and capital gains are taxed
questions.explanation: Corporate income is taxed first as corporate profit, then shareholders pay personal tax on dividends received.

questions.question: A key disadvantage of going public through an IPO is:
questions.explanation: Public companies must comply with extensive disclosure requirements, accounting standards, and regulatory oversight.

concepts.title: Debt vs Equity Claims
concepts.desc: Debt: fixed claims, priority in liquidation, limited upside. Equity: residual claims, last in liquidation, unlimited upside.

concepts.title: Shareholder-Creditor Conflict
concepts.desc: Shareholders benefit from higher risk (upside). Creditors prefer lower risk (protect fixed claims). Asset substitution problem.

concepts.title: Stakeholder Theory
concepts.desc: Company should consider all stakeholders: shareholders, creditors, employees, customers, suppliers, government, communities.

concepts.title: ESG Considerations
concepts.desc: Environmental (climate, pollution), Social (labor, diversity), Governance (board, executive pay). Increasingly material to investment decisions.

concepts.title: Agency Problem
concepts.desc: Conflict between principals (shareholders) and agents (managers). Managers may pursue self-interest over shareholder wealth maximization.

decisions.question: Shareholder vs Stakeholder approach?
use: Shareholder: maximize firm value for owners (traditional)
Stakeholder: consider all parties, sustainable long-term value
avoid: Ignoring stakeholders entirely â€” can create legal, reputational, operational risk

pitfalls: Equity holders have limited downside (limited liability) but unlimited upside â€” they prefer risk
Creditors have limited upside (fixed payments) but face downside â€” they prefer safety
ESG risks can be financially material â€” not just ethical considerations

questions.question: In a liquidation, which claim holders are paid first?
questions.explanation: Priority: secured creditors > unsecured creditors > subordinated debt > preferred equity > common equity.

questions.question: The asset substitution problem occurs when:
options: Managers invest in riskier assets to benefit equity holders at the expense of creditors
Companies sell assets below fair value
Dividends are paid from borrowed funds
questions.explanation: Equity holders prefer riskier investments (more upside), which transfers wealth from creditors (who bear the downside risk).

questions.question: Which ESG factor relates to board composition and executive compensation?
questions.explanation: Governance encompasses board structure, independence, executive compensation, shareholder rights, and transparency.

modules.title: Corporate Governance: Conflicts, Mechanisms, Risks, and Benefits

concepts.title: Principal-Agent Conflict
concepts.desc: Managers (agents) may not always act in shareholders' (principals') best interest. Monitoring and incentive alignment needed.

concepts.title: Controlling vs Minority Shareholders
concepts.desc: Controlling shareholders may extract private benefits at minority shareholders' expense. Tunneling, related-party transactions.

concepts.title: Board of Directors
concepts.desc: Elected by shareholders to oversee management. Key: independence, diversity, separation of CEO/Chair roles.

concepts.title: Governance Mechanisms
concepts.desc: Internal: board, audits, compensation design, codes of conduct. External: regulations, market for corporate control, shareholder activism.

concepts.title: Shareholder Activism
concepts.desc: Proxy fights, shareholder proposals, engagement with management. Hedge fund activism, ESG-focused activism.

decisions.question: Good vs Poor governance signals?
use: Good: independent board, separate CEO/Chair, transparent disclosure, aligned incentives
Red flags: dual-class shares, related-party transactions, weak audit committee

pitfalls: Board independence is about financial/personal ties, not just employment status
Good governance doesn't guarantee good performance, but poor governance increases risk
Dual-class share structures can entrench management and harm minority shareholders

questions.question: Separation of the CEO and Board Chair roles is recommended because it:
options: Is required by law in all countries
questions.explanation: Separating the roles ensures the board can independently oversee and evaluate the CEO without conflicts of interest.

questions.question: Tunneling in corporate governance refers to:
options: Transferring company assets to controlling shareholders
questions.explanation: Tunneling is the extraction of corporate assets/value by controlling shareholders through related-party transactions, excessive compensation, or other means.

concepts.title: Working Capital
concepts.desc: Current assets - Current liabilities. Measures short-term financial health and operational efficiency.

concepts.title: Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC)
concepts.desc: DOH + DSO - DPO. Days to convert raw materials to cash. Lower CCC = more efficient working capital management.

concepts.title: Liquidity Sources
concepts.desc: Primary: cash, receivables, inventory, credit lines. Secondary: liquidating assets, renegotiating debt, filing bankruptcy.

concepts.title: Drags on Liquidity
concepts.desc: Delay cash inflows: uncollected receivables, obsolete inventory, tight credit markets.

concepts.title: Pulls on Liquidity
concepts.desc: Accelerate cash outflows: early payments to suppliers, reduced credit terms from suppliers, unexpected expenses.

formulas.name: Cash Conversion Cycle
formulas.where: DOH = Days of Inventory on Hand, DSO = Days Sales Outstanding, DPO = Days Payable Outstanding

formulas.name: Current Ratio
formulas.formula: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities
formulas.where: Higher = more liquid, but too high may indicate inefficiency

formulas.name: Quick Ratio
formulas.formula: Quick Ratio = (Cash + Receivables + ST Investments) / Current Liabilities

decisions.question: How to improve CCC?
use: Reduce DOH: better inventory management, JIT
Reduce DSO: faster collection, stricter credit terms
Increase DPO: negotiate longer payment terms with suppliers
avoid: Stretching payables too far (damages supplier relationships)
Offering too-aggressive credit terms to boost sales

pitfalls: A negative CCC means the company collects cash from customers before paying suppliers (e.g., Amazon)
Current ratio may be misleading if current assets are mostly illiquid inventory
Working capital needs vary by industry â€” compare within industry

examples.title: Cash Conversion Cycle
examples.problem: DOH = 45 days, DSO = 30 days, DPO = 40 days. Calculate CCC.
examples.solution: CCC = 45 + 30 - 40 = 35 days. The company takes 35 days from paying for inventory to receiving cash from sales.

questions.question: DOH = 50, DSO = 35, DPO = 45. The cash conversion cycle is:
A drag on liquidity is best described as:
questions.explanation: Drags delay cash inflows (e.g., slow-paying customers, obsolete inventory).

questions.question: A company with a negative CCC:
options: Collects from customers before paying suppliers
questions.explanation: A negative CCC means the company receives cash from sales before it needs to pay its suppliers â€” effectively using supplier financing.

concepts.title: Net Present Value (NPV)
concepts.desc: Sum of PV of all cash flows (including initial investment). Accept if NPV > 0. The theoretically best capital budgeting method.

concepts.title: Internal Rate of Return (IRR)
concepts.desc: Discount rate that makes NPV = 0. Accept if IRR > required return. May conflict with NPV for mutually exclusive projects.

concepts.title: Payback Period
concepts.desc: Time to recover initial investment. Simple but ignores TVM and cash flows after payback.

concepts.title: Return on Invested Capital (ROIC)
concepts.desc: NOPAT / Invested Capital. Measures how efficiently capital is deployed. Create value when ROIC > WACC.

concepts.title: Real Options
concepts.desc: Options embedded in capital projects: option to delay, expand, abandon, or switch. Add value beyond NPV.

concepts.title: Capital Allocation Pitfalls
concepts.desc: Sunk cost fallacy, pet projects, failure to consider opportunity costs, optimism bias, anchoring.

formulas.name: NPV
formulas.where: r = required return (WACC for firm projects)

formulas.name: IRR
formulas.where: IRR = rate where NPV equals zero

formulas.name: Payback Period
formulas.formula: Payback = Years before full recovery + (Unrecovered amount / CF in recovery year)

formulas.name: ROIC
formulas.where: NOPAT = Net Operating Profit After Tax

decisions.question: NPV vs IRR: which to follow?
use: NPV: always correct ranking for mutually exclusive projects
IRR: useful for communication (percentage return is intuitive)
avoid: Following IRR when it conflicts with NPV â€” NPV maximizes shareholder wealth
Using IRR with non-conventional cash flows (multiple IRRs possible)

pitfalls: NPV and IRR can give conflicting rankings for mutually exclusive projects â€” ALWAYS follow NPV
IRR assumes reinvestment at IRR, NPV at WACC (more realistic)
Non-conventional cash flows can produce multiple IRRs or no IRR
Sunk costs should be IGNORED in capital budgeting â€” only incremental CFs matter
Include opportunity costs (e.g., if a warehouse could be rented out)

examples.title: NPV Calculation
examples.problem: Project costs $100,000 today. CFs: Year 1 = $40,000, Year 2 = $50,000, Year 3 = $60,000. WACC = 10%. Calculate NPV.

branches.label: NPV
leaves: PV of all CFs minus cost

questions.question: When NPV and IRR give conflicting rankings for mutually exclusive projects, an analyst should:
questions.explanation: NPV directly measures the value added to the firm. When NPV and IRR conflict, NPV is correct because it assumes reinvestment at the cost of capital (more realistic).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a limitation of the payback period?
options: Ignores cash flows after the payback period
Does not account for the time value of money
Does not provide a measure of profitability
questions.explanation: Being easy to calculate is an advantage, not a limitation. The payback period's limitations include ignoring TVM and cash flows beyond the payback period.

questions.question: A company creates value when:
questions.explanation: Value is created when the return on invested capital exceeds the cost of that capital (WACC). This means the firm is earning more than its investors require.

questions.question: Sunk costs should be:
options: Included if they are large enough
Excluded from the capital budgeting analysis
questions.explanation: Sunk costs are already spent and irrecoverable. Only incremental future cash flows should be included in capital budgeting.

concepts.title: WACC
concepts.desc: Weighted average cost of capital = w<sub>d</sub>r<sub>d</sub>(1-t) + w<sub>e</sub>r<sub>e</sub>. Blended cost of debt and equity financing.

concepts.title: MM Proposition I (no taxes)
concepts.desc: Capital structure is irrelevant to firm value in perfect markets. V<sub>L</sub> = V<sub>U</sub>.

concepts.title: MM Proposition II (no taxes)
concepts.desc: Cost of equity increases linearly with leverage: r<sub>e</sub> = r<sub>0</sub> + (r<sub>0</sub> - r<sub>d</sub>) Ã— D/E.

concepts.title: MM with Taxes
concepts.desc: Debt creates a tax shield: V<sub>L</sub> = V<sub>U</sub> + tÃ—D. More debt increases firm value through interest tax deductibility.

concepts.title: Optimal Capital Structure
concepts.desc: Balances tax benefits of debt against costs of financial distress. Minimizes WACC, maximizes firm value.

concepts.title: Pecking Order Theory
concepts.desc: Firms prefer: 1) Internal financing, 2) Debt, 3) Equity. Due to information asymmetry â€” issuing equity signals overvaluation.

formulas.name: WACC
formulas.formula: WACC = w<sub>d</sub> Ã— r<sub>d</sub> Ã— (1-t) + w<sub>e</sub> Ã— r<sub>e</sub>
formulas.where: w = weight, r<sub>d</sub> = cost of debt, r<sub>e</sub> = cost of equity, t = tax rate

formulas.name: MM Prop I (with taxes)
formulas.where: Tax shield increases levered firm value

formulas.name: Cost of Equity (CAPM)
formulas.where: r<sub>f</sub> = risk-free rate, Î² = beta, r<sub>m</sub> - r<sub>f</sub> = market risk premium

decisions.question: More debt or more equity?
use: More debt: stable cash flows, high tax rate, low financial distress costs (e.g., utilities)
More equity: volatile cash flows, high growth, significant intangible assets (e.g., tech)
avoid: Too much debt for cyclical businesses â€” financial distress costs dominate

pitfalls: WACC uses MARKET value weights, not book value weights
MM propositions assume perfect markets â€” real world has taxes, distress costs, agency costs
Adding debt reduces WACC (tax shield) up to a point, then distress costs increase it
Pecking order explains WHY firms prefer internal funds first

examples.title: WACC Calculation
examples.problem: D/V = 40%, E/V = 60%, r<sub>d</sub> = 5%, r<sub>e</sub> = 12%, tax = 30%. Calculate WACC.

branches.label: MM Propositions
leaves: With taxes: debt adds value (tax shield)
Cost of equity rises with leverage

questions.question: Given: D/V=30%, E/V=70%, r<sub>d</sub>=6%, r<sub>e</sub>=14%, tax=25%. WACC is closest to:
According to MM Proposition I with taxes, firm value is maximized when:
options: The firm is at its optimal capital structure
Capital structure does not affect firm value
questions.explanation: Under MM with taxes (without bankruptcy costs), more debt always adds value through the tax shield. In theory, 100% debt maximizes value. In reality, distress costs limit this.

questions.question: According to pecking order theory, a firm will issue equity:
options: Whenever the stock price is high
questions.explanation: Pecking order: internal funds > debt > equity. Firms issue equity last because it signals to the market that shares may be overvalued.

questions.question: The tax shield benefit of debt equals:
options: Total debt Ã— cost of equity
questions.explanation: Tax shield = Interest Ã— t. Interest is tax-deductible, so the government effectively pays t% of interest costs.

concepts.title: Business Model
concepts.desc: How a company creates, delivers, and captures value. Defines: who are customers, what is offered, how to deliver, how to earn revenue.

concepts.title: Value Proposition
concepts.desc: The unique combination of products/services that creates value for a specific customer segment.

concepts.title: Revenue Models
concepts.desc: Subscription, licensing, advertising, transaction-based, freemium, razor-and-blade.

concepts.title: Network Effects
concepts.desc: Value of product/service increases as more users adopt it. Creates competitive moats (e.g., social media, payment networks).

concepts.title: Platform Business Models
concepts.desc: Connect multiple user groups (buyers/sellers, riders/drivers). Capture value by facilitating transactions. Network effects amplify growth.

concepts.title: Business Model Innovation
concepts.desc: New ways to create or capture value. Disruption when incumbents' models become obsolete (e.g., streaming vs DVD rental).

decisions.question: How to evaluate a business model?
avoid: Assuming past business model success guarantees future performance

pitfalls: Network effects can work in reverse â€” user loss accelerates as network shrinks
Platform businesses need to solve the chicken-and-egg problem (getting both sides simultaneously)
Freemium models require sufficient conversion to paid tier for profitability

questions.question: A network effect exists when:
options: A company has a large sales network
The value of a product increases as more people use it
The cost of production decreases with scale
A company partners with other firms
questions.explanation: Network effects mean each additional user increases the value for all users (e.g., a social network becomes more valuable with more members).

questions.question: A platform business model primarily creates value by:
options: Connecting different user groups and facilitating interactions
questions.explanation: Platforms connect producers with consumers, riders with drivers, etc. and capture value by enabling and facilitating these interactions.
